Identity & Self Awareness

Start module

Part 1: Self Awareness

Ella (18) - Young person from the States of Mind Team

Discussion

What does self awareness mean to you?

Common misconceptions about self awareness

Self awareness is narcissistic

It’s when you are really self absorbed

Self awareness is impossible to maintain

You either have self awareness or you don’t

So what is self awareness?

Self awareness is the experience of noticing your thoughts, feelings and behaviour, as if you are an observer.

It also allows you to step back and understand yourself and how you are affected by other people.

By developing your levels of self awareness, you can access a sense of choice around how you respond to life’s challenges. Over time, you can experience a deep connection with your most authentic self.

And what are the benefits of developing Self Awareness?

Self awareness is a tool that can help us to grow

The insights that self awareness provides you with allow you to feel more satisfied with your life because you become more aware of why you feel and act the way you do.

When cultivated fully, you no longer feel the need to repress or hide your emotions or react unconsciously to your experiences but will view yourself with a deeper level of understanding.

Harrington, Rick,Loffredo, Donald 2010/11/30, Insight, Rumination, and Self-Reflection as Predictors of Well-Being, The Journal of psychology

Self awareness enables you to:

Take responsibility for your problems.

By developing knowledge about yourself and understanding yourself more fully, you can determine where your problems are coming from so that you can begin to resolve them more easily.

Improve your relationships

By being more aware of how you are acting towards yourself and in your relationships, you can improve the quality of these relationships, which are so key for experiencing a fulfilling life.

Improve your confidence

People with self awareness have more clarity about who they are, what they believe in and what their personal goals are. Without this clarity, it can be easy to lack self assurance and struggle with your self esteem.

Psychology provides us with different models to understand and develop self awareness.

This module will introduce you to 3 of those models:

  • Johari Window

  • Inner child

  • Subpersonalities

The Johari Window

The Johari Window is a visual representation of the parts of yourself that are either known or unknown to you and the people in your life.

  • The open area The parts of yourself that you are aware of and that other people know about you too.

  • The hidden area The parts of yourself that you do not share with others. This information that you keep private may relate to your fears and insecurities as well as your hopes and dreams.

  • The blind spot The parts of yourself you are not aware of but that others know about you. This can relate to both your positive attributes and your areas for growth.

  • The unknown This relates to the the parts of yourself that you are not aware of yet and which nobody else knows either.

Explore your Johari Window

Part 2: Identity

What is it about a person that defines who they are? 

Who are you?

Explore your identity

Go to handbook

Identity

Your identity isn’t fixed but develops and changes over time. It is subjective and personal and is influenced by your unique life experiences.

As your life history and identity are so closely related, exploring and bringing awareness to different aspects of your identity can provide an important foundation for self-discovery, self awareness and personal growth. 

Your Name

Your name

Your name is a personal and special aspect of your identity. People are very familiar with this part of their identity, yet they do not always pause to consider the meaning their name has for them.

The act of bringing conscious awareness to an aspect of yourself such as your name allows you to connect more deeply with your sense of who you are and the meaning it holds for you. 

Reflect on your name

Go to handbook

Life events and Personal History

Explore your personal history

Go to handbook

Authenticity and mental health

Carl Jung was a Swiss Psychologist who explored the personality and human nature.

Jung believed that ‘individuation’ was the main purpose of human development.

Individuation is the process through which a person achieves a sense of individuality separate from the identities of others.

His idea was that psychological health is achieved by seeking to live as authentically as you can ( to feel and act in accordance with who you most essentially are).

“There is in the psyche a process that seeks its own goal no matter what the external factors may be….the almost irresistible compulsion and urge to become what one is.”   

Carl Jung 

What is real?

What is our authentic self ?

Under the many layers of your identity and your personality is your true self, this part of you never changes but exists throughout your life as your innermost being. This part of yourself exists independently of your thoughts, feelings and roles that you play in the world.

When you are connected with your authentic self, you are able to live freely, without feeling the need to be anybody else. In this place, you accept your qualities, attributes and innate gifts and can live according to who you most essentially are.

Throughout your life, you change and adapt parts of yourself to maintain your relationships with others and to fit in to who you think other people want you to be. Everyone experiences this conflict between wanting to be true to themselves and wanting to fit in with the world around them.

This next part of the module will explore the authentic self and how you develop the different ‘masks’ or sub-personalities that you show to the world.

The Younger You

Inner child Practice

The inner child practice is a therapeutic process that allows you to reconnect with your essential nature.

As a young child, you do not change or adapt your behaviour for others but express your needs, interests and sense of self authentically.

By reconnecting with your younger self, you can discover and reclaim lost qualities of yourself and bring them into your present life to help you.

This is a therapeutic process that can help you to develop your self awareness and self esteem.

Inner child reflection

Go to handbook

Part 3: Personality

Personality

Personality comes from the greek word ‘persona’ which means mask.

Your personality refers to the different ways you express yourself in the world and the many different ways you relate with other people.

Together with your personality you have an unchanging part of who you you are that psychologists call the ‘Self’. This is the part of you that does not change over time or adapt to different circumstances, but is your essential nature.

Your Self is the part of you that is spontaneous and loving, that seeks to be known and is the experience of who you most fundamentally are.

The psychology of Sub-personalities

Subpersonalities are habits or patterns of behaviour that you have followed since childhood.

When people fail to respond empathetically to your true personality, you learn to hide your authentic nature and adapt to how your parents or other people tell you that you should be.

A psychotherapist called Winnicott also called this process of adapting, the development of the False Self. It has also been referred to as the Survival Personality or ‘Character Armour’. 

They are distinct patterns of thoughts, feelings and behaviours that you develop to adapt to various environments where you feel unable to be your authentic self.

In neuroscience these are viewed as distinct neural networks that function as ‘specialised selves’ or ‘self states’.

Sub-personality theory explains personality development and helps to explain why parts of your personality can feel conflicted and as if there are ‘multiple selves’ within you who have different ways of being.

For example the feeling of ‘I want to do this but another part of me wants to do that’, or ‘ I am angry right now but I think its important I tell the truth’

Siegel 1993

" The false self is set up to protect the true self - to respond to challenges in the environment - the false self essentially takes up the role of social compliance. "

Donald Winnicott

How are sub-personalities related to mental health? 

Subpersonalities cause difficulties when you identify with this one part of yourself and believe it to be all of you.

For example, if you are identified with the ‘High achiever’ part of yourself, it may help you to get good grades and maintain a motivation for developing your knowledge and experience. However, if you become over identified with this part of yourself you may become very distressed by setbacks, you may spend less time with our friends or you may never be satisfied with what you have achieved. 

Your sub personalities all emerge from an unmet need.By identifying these needs you can develop more self awareness and understanding of your behaviour.

By bringing awareness to your different sub personalities you can integrate them and enable the different parts of your personality to work together as a harmonious whole.

Exploring sub personalities

Example: The Expert

Behaviour: Patronising, condescending, arrogant, ‘ know it all’, rigid, defensive, guarded and slightly hostile. Serious tone of voice. Body language: Rigid, tense, stiff.

Wants: To be taken seriously, to be respected, not to be challenged, to be right, to feel superior, to be admired and given attention. to not be criticised.

Needs: To feel unconditionally accepted and loved, to be seen and valued, to be heard, to feel worthy and enough as they are.

Qualities of self that are hidden: Playfulness and spontaneity, willingness to learn from others, curiosity, the part of us that wants to grow, acceptance of self.

Explore your subpersonalities

Go to handbook

What are the benefits of sub-personality work? 

  1. You learn to connect with your different and contradictory ways of acting in the world. This raises your awareness of your behaviour and helps you to make sense of how you can seem to be different versions of yourself in different circumstances.

  2. You learn to free yourself of the unconscious forces that cause you to get trapped in certain aspects of your personality. For example, a very critical part of yourself.

  3. You integrate the different aspects of your personality which causes you to feel less conflict within yourself.

  4. You emphasise all of the beneficial qualities of your sub-personalities and recognise how they serve you.

  5. By identifying with your different sub-peronalities, it allows you to develop a greater awareness of what is your true self and what is a mask or persona.

Some other sub-personalities for you to explore

  • The clown
  • The critic
  • The people pleaser
  • The caretaker
  • The rebel
  • The high achiever
  • The child

Stages of Integration

  • Recognition

  • Acceptance

  • Coordination

  • Integration

  • Synthesis

If you would like to learn more the psychology of personality you can explore the Enneagram, Myers Briggs and the Big Five Personality test.

It is important to recognise that personality tests highlight aspects of your personality by showing you dominant traits not your complete self.

Part 4: Society and Identity

Quiz

Quiz 1
Quiz 2
Quiz 3
Quiz 4

"Belonging is the innate human desire to be part of something larger than us. Because this yearning is so primal, we often try to acquire it by fitting in and by seeking approval, which are not only hollow substitutes for belonging, but often barriers to it...”

Brene Brown

"...Because true belonging only happens when we present our authentic, imperfect selves to the world, our sense of belonging can never be greater than our level of self-acceptance.”

Brene Brown

You live in a social world and many aspects of your personality is shaped by the social relationships and situations you encounter throughout your life.

As it is impossible for your close relationships to be fully present all the time and for you to be completely present to others, you fit your environments by adapting your personality to defend yourself and meet your needs for connection.

An example of this is noticing when somebody seems to have a different personality depending on what group they are in, or when you notice you behave differently depending on who you are with.

This is a completely normal process but understanding the process behind it can help you develop an awareness of how parts of your identity are shaped by your desire to fit in and be accepted in contrast to expressing your authentic feelings and experince when you are with others.

Exploring our relationship with groups

Group Identity  

Values, Beliefs and Behaviour

One of the strongest factors that influence and reflect your sense of identity are the groups that you are a part of in your life.

From the moment you are born, you are a part of your family group. As you grow and develop, you encounter new groups at school or in our local community. Throughout your whole life, out of choice or out of circumstance, you will spend your times in groups that have an influence on you and which reflect your values, beliefs and mindsets about who you are.

Groups provide a sense of belonging, which is one of the most important needs in terms of mental health and wellbeing. Research has shown consistently that the quality of your social world is one of the most significant indicators of your wellbeing and ability to recover from difficult times in your life.

Explore your relationship with groups

Go to handbook
